Disgusting:
Apple and Google are "accomplices in the oppression of Saudi Arabian women.":
https://t.co/9ZDmp3IIvi https://t.co/C37m0H7FNP
@mediafinger My dude, how this glitch makes it ok for a company to work with a totalitarian regime on streamlining the oppression and control of another human eludes me.

@mediafinger No, this is exactly what that article is about. THAT discussion.
"The ingenuity of American technology companies should not be perverted to violate the human rights of Saudi women. Twenty first century innovations should not perpetuate sixteenth century tyranny."

@mediafinger Google and Apple chose to help in the commodification and digitization of human trafficking. They help to keep this system in place and make it even more efficient. There is no upside in it, for nobody.

@mediafinger Your argument that a glitch makes the oppression better for women and slave workers comes from a perverted techno loving point of view which assumes that everybody is able to use a smartphone.

@mediafinger Tech is the problem, because now with it you can fix glitches easily. Unauthorized access? Use finger print, facial recognition.
With smartphones in the picture you could even implement a short lived push notification based system to "approve" travel on border controls.

@mediafinger Google and Apple provide their platform knowingly to these atrocities but decide to take a neutral position and say: this is legal.

THAT is the point here.

In the past I used to define an interface (in TypeScript) which defines instance methods:
https://t.co/wBbgs9C8RV

I struggle in turning the implementation (e.g. this one: https://t.co/96FpTjUVmJ) into something nice.

Removing `this` in the class methods and turning them into pure functions which receive the `findAll` method as a parameter does not look nice.
Some pointers / ideas would be greatly appreciated.

@emsuiko Keep learning. You are never done.
@w3ltraumpirat I have my source in @papercall_io and adapt from there.

@netzvagabund @emsuiko You could time-box it: make a list of all the topics you want to learn and distill that down to ~10 if there too many. Then spent a short time (1-2 hours) per topic to learn about the basics (watch an Intro video on YT or do the Getting Started guide if it's software).
@netzvagabund @emsuiko After that you should have a better understanding of what makes sense for you. And you will also discover related topics, and even the underlying principles to learn.
How to figure out what to learn next: https://t.co/Pvws7mEl2A

@emsuiko No, oftentimes not, because we get told in school&uni: learn this and you are ready for to job marked. 
That can lead to the false assumption that you have learned everything necessary once you start working.

@einarwh You make a very good point: the value is created through collaboration, not by producing code.

But, a lot of the issues you point out with Softwarecraft"men" are in my experience no longer valid. As a community we moved beyond those years ago.

@einarwh I invite you to join us at one of the many Software Crafters unconferences around Europe, maybe @SoCraTes_Conf in August, or @codefreeze_fi in January. You can find more on https://t.co/zCoTsgR8yL.
@einarwh @SoCraTes_Conf @codefreeze_fi You will find that we mostly talk about the important stuff that happens when we are not sitting in front of our keyboards...

@einarwh @SoCraTes_Conf @codefreeze_fi Yes, those will always be around. But it is especially great for me that they have been made obsolete and there are many new crafters who join our community every year.
It surprised even me: https://t.co/2aE3MIoecD

Now @Scott_Helme talks about how he hacks products and how easy it can be for anyone to get started. https://t.co/ptkvnE9YHJ

"The representation of hackers in general media is so far off from what I do actually, it's terrible.
The one show that gets close is Mr. Robot."
Going to tech meetups in Trondheim is depressing. 40 attendees, all white men. #Diversity

Hacking products is fun and easy but, when flaws are exposed the real world consequences can be a mess: bankruptcies, services taken down. It's good that Scott has the BBC backing him and his work. https://t.co/BNtkxIu0LF
No special tools required to hack web applications, start with your browser's developer tools and use a proxy like https://t.co/H03Uvxfcdi for easier manipulate and replay requests.

A lot of the stories @Scott_Helme shares are caused by terrible web application security.

It's never a wrong time to revisit the @owasp top 10: https://t.co/fLndpGSseX https://t.co/odeabFRAu9

If a security researcher contacts you, they don't have an agenda, they want to help you.
If they had bad intentions they would not disclose a security issue but exploit it without you knowing.
